item.title: Football Manager 26 Was Helped By Last Year‚Äôs Cancellation, Developer Says
item.content:encoded:
Football Manager 26 wouldn‚Äôt have reached its current level of polish and quality if last year‚Äôs entry hadn‚Äôt been scrapped, so says Sports Interactive Design Manager Ant Farley.

The game marks a significant step for the franchise as it leaves behind the Sports Interactive Operating System engine in favor of the Unity engine. This change saw Football Manager 25 suffer through multiple delays and feature cuts before ultimately being cancelled to focus on making sure the game was up to the standards that players have come to expect from the 20+ year franchise.

In an interview with Football Gaming Zone, Farley says that canceling last year‚Äôs game wasn‚Äôt an easy choice to make, but it was necessary.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no way we‚Äôd have been able to reach the same level of quality that FM26 currently has if we shipped FM25,‚Äù Farley said. ‚ÄúSome of the decisions where we rethought and changed direction, we‚Äôd have had to push them out there if we released FM25. And, once they‚Äôre out in the world, it becomes difficult to rethink it. We probably would have needed to fix them, rather than rethink them.‚Äù

He added that instead of building a complete game, they would‚Äôve been spending more time fixing bugs than anything else. But with the focus shifting towards Football Manager 26 instead, it gave them even more determination to make the best game possible.

‚ÄúThe original disappointment [of the cancellation] ‚Äúwas tangible, but it quickly made way to an attitude of ‚Äòlet‚Äôs crack on now, we‚Äôve got a chance to make something we are really proud of, ‚Äò‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt proud of FM25, we didn‚Äôt think it offered good value for money for our playerbase, and that‚Äôs our real motivating factor.

‚ÄúWhen we had news of the cancellation, it gave us the determination to get it right for FM26.‚Äù

Football Manager 26 launches on November 4. An open beta will be taking place starting October 24, with progress being able to be brought over to the full game post-launch.

For more Insider Gaming, read about Mexico moving closer to adding a tax on the sales of violent video games. And don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Battlefield 6 is Great, But There‚Äôs Still One Feature I Want Back
item.content:encoded:
Battlefield 6 continues to impress gamers, and there‚Äôs still an immense amount of life left in a roadmap that‚Äôs yet to deliver the game‚Äôs first multiplayer season and a free-to-play battle royale component. In my review, I rated Battlefield 6 highly on account of its stellar multiplayer platform, but points were detracted for the less-than-desirable campaign portion of the game.

As I play Battlefield 6, I can‚Äôt help but find myself lusting after a feature from bygone days that hasn‚Äôt been seen in a Battlefield game since 2018‚Äôs Battlefield 5. It‚Äôs something I adored in the World War II shooter that added a layer of immersion and ownership, but it‚Äôs not present in Battlefield 6, and I mourn the loss of it.

I Want To Fortify Objectives in Battlefield 6

In Battlefield 5 (2018), users could take over an objective in a mode like Conquest or Breakthrough and set about fortifying it. They‚Äôd pull out their toolkit and construct everything from tank traps to sandbag walls. They could board windows, dig trenches, install machine gun nests, and set up barbed wire fences.

It was all pre-determined and linear, but it gave players a sense of ownership over an objective. They could capture the spot and then fully fortify it, preparing for the inevitable retake attempt from the opposing team.

It was also a nice way to earn an extra chunk of experience points, with the game‚Äôs support class having abilities that allowed them to craft fortifications faster.

Sadly, this feature was removed going into Battlefield 2042 (because the game lacked destruction), and it hasn‚Äôt resurfaced in Battlefield 6, which was released on October 10.

This is a shame, as Battlefield 6 has wonderful destruction that can see buildings razed to the ground, and I could imagine fortifications becoming progressively ramshackle as objectives crumble to dust under the weight of incoming fire.

RELATED: What Should Battlefield 6 Take From Battlefield 5?

The idea came to me again while occupying objective ‚ÄòD‚Äô on Liberation Peak, which is a site set in the middle of a road flanked by houses, all of which are begging for fortifications. It would be the best spot to lay some tank traps to prevent vehicular pushes from either end of the street, and the ruined houses are perfect for sandbagging and trenches.

I can fully appreciate why this isn‚Äôt a thing, of course. Battlefield 6 is a fast-paced game with immense destruction mechanics, and any fortifications would likely be taken out the second they‚Äôre built. It‚Äôs not worth the development time to implement something that can so quickly be destroyed.

Being an objective player, I‚Äôll forever wish for the integration of fortifications. It‚Äôs the perfect way to gain a sense of ownership over an objective, and it‚Äôs a way for players less skilled in the gunny space to earn extra experience points and complete challenges.

Do you wish Battlefield 6 had fortifications? Let me know what you‚Äôre thinking on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more Insider Gaming coverage, check out the news that Springfield might be coming to Fortnite in a Simpsons-themed crossover

item.title: All Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A Wild Zone 3 Spawns & Alpha Pok√©mon Locations
item.content:encoded:
Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A has a different approach to other Pok√©mon games regarding spawn locations, with some fixed odds available across Lumiose City, and we‚Äôve got a breakdown of all the Pok√©mon you can encounter in Wild Zone 3.

In total, Lumiose City has 20 Wild Zones to explore in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A, which are unlocked periodically throughout story progression, with unique spawns scattered throughout, with many Pok√©mon only being obtainable at one specific location.

If you‚Äôre on the hunt for missing Pok√©mon from Wild Zone 3, we‚Äôve got all the important details here.

Just like Wild Zone 2, Wild Zone 4 is unlocked in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A as soon as you reach Main Mission 5 and progress through the introductory points of the game.

There are six species in total that are found in Wild Zone 3, all of which need to be caught to complete Mable‚Äôs Research Tasks, one of which has Mega Evolution potential later in the story. However, others can still be core members of your party, particularly through early periodsd of the game.

In the table below, we‚Äôve listed all the Pok√©mon that spawn in Wild Zone 3, the time of day they appear, and notes on the specific location where they can be found.

Wild Zone 3 in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A has one guaranteed Alpha Pok√©mon that is present in the same spot both day and night.

However, every Pok√©mon in Legends: Z-A has a fixed chance of spawning as an Alpha, while others have set spawns that can be rotated with other Pok√©mon. In WIld Zone 3, however, there‚Äôs only one guaranteed Alpha spawn that you will encounter whenever you visit the area.

All the details you need on Alpha Pok√©mon in Wild Zone 4 are below.

What Shiny Pok√©mon have you caught so far in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A? Brag about your finds in the Insider Gaming Discord.

For more Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A, find out where to get your hands on all Mega Evolutions in the game, and take a look at all the special Evolution requirements.

item.title: Has The ARC Raiders Server Slam Playtest Been Extended? When Does The Playtest End?
item.content:encoded:
It‚Äôs no secret how popular ARC Raiders has been all year. The extraction shooter has undergone a bunch of playtests and betas, and the Server Slam open beta arrived just before launch. If you‚Äôre wondering whether the latest ARC Raiders playtest is still going, when it ends, and if there‚Äôs another on the way, we‚Äôve got answers to every question.

You only have to look at how many playtests Embark Studios has conducted this year to see how steadfast the developer is in its desire to get ARC Raiders right. Escape From Tarkov is finally ready for its 1.0 release, but this has possibly been pushed forward by the success and interest in ARC Raiders‚Äîits new extraction shooter competition.

If you‚Äôve enjoyed the Server Slam playtest and want to play more, we‚Äôve got details on the beta and the game‚Äôs future.

Is The ARC Raiders Server Slam Playtest Over?

The ARC Raiders Server Slam Playtest officially ended on October 20, and confirmation came from official ARC Raiders social media to end all hopes of the beta being extended.

There‚Äôs always an optimistic instinct in all of us that we might get more. An extra day off, a bit more money in a paycheck, or anything equivalent. That was the feeling in the ARC Raiders community with the Server Slam test. Even though this was a last-minute beta before launch, the thought of waiting nearly two weeks for the game is probably an eternity.

We‚Äôve seen people frantically looking up to see if the playtest had been extended. This is where we break your heart and say that this particular beta has conclusively ended.

Will There Be Another ARC Raiders Playtest?

Embark Studios‚Äô stance is that the Server Slam playtest was the final beta of any sort before ARC Raiders finally launches on October 30.

Here‚Äôs what the official ARC Raiders account on X had to say: ‚ÄúThe Server Slam has now officially ended. Thank you so much for joining us to test the servers before the big day. Speranza awaits you on October 30th, Raiders!‚Äù

As you can see, there‚Äôs no mention of a final final playtest. It‚Äôs safe to say we‚Äôre ready to go for launch. It‚Äôs been a long journey to get there‚Äîwhat the delay and all‚Äîbut, hopefully, it‚Äôs all worth it!

Could the team spring one final playtest on us as a tease? If they do, you know where to go to find out: Here on the Insider Gaming official website, or by keeping up with the wider IG community via the Insider Gaming Discord.

We encourage you to check out more of our ARC Raiders guides and handy articles to keep your patience in check. We have details on its price and if it‚Äôs free to play, if there‚Äôs any Launch Early Access, and why you should be optimistic if you don‚Äôt like traditional extraction shooter progression wipes.

item.title: ARC Raiders Price Explained‚ÄîWill ARC Raiders Be Free To Play?
item.content:encoded:
Embark Studios is bringing serious competition to the extraction shooter genre in 2025 with ARC Raiders. The futuristic shooter has all the hallmarks of a classic PvPvE experience, and it would score more points if it were free to play and didn‚Äôt have a price to pay.

ARC Raiders became Steam‚Äôs most popular Extraction Shooter with the release of its final test phase before launch‚Äîthe open beta Server Slam Test. Developer Embark Studios (known for The Finals) has worked very hard to ensure it learns from its mistakes and stands a chance of survival at release.

One way to get more people on board is to make ARC Raiders free-to-play. Foregoing a price might be a financial gamble, but there would be benefits. Let‚Äôs raid the information cabinet for you.

Is ARC Raiders Free-to-Play?

ARC Raiders will not be a free-to-play online multiplayer experience, and you will have to pay an initial one-time fee to set foot in Speranza and beyond!

There‚Äôs a definite line in the sand when it comes to online shooters now: Those that are free-to-play, and those that want a fee upfront. Naturally, games like Concord have only stoked the fires of the debate more. When you have a Warzone, a Fortnite, a Marvel Rivals, or an Apex Legends charging nothing to play the base game, it‚Äôs only natural to question if other new releases should follow suit.

However, EA and Embark Studios have decided against making ARC Raiders free-to-play. It doesn‚Äôt mean it won‚Äôt make the transition in the future, but for now, you need to dip into your pockets to play it.

ARC Raiders Price, Explained

The base edition of ARC Raiders costs $39.99 or ¬£30.99, whereas you need to stump up $59.99 or ¬£49.99 for the more expensive Deluxe Edition.

Obviously, you don‚Äôt need to buy the upgraded version, but the Deluxe Edition content and bonus rewards are pretty tempting. The Standard Edition offers the thing you‚Äôre after the most‚Äîthe game. If you go early, you might even be able to get your hands on the ARC Raiders pre-order bonuses.

Here‚Äôs a mini-breakdown of what‚Äôs included in each edition of the game, and a reaffirmation of the cost.

Which ARC Raiders edition will you go for? Are you disappointed to learn that the extraction shooter isn‚Äôt free-to-play? Let us know your thoughts and more through the Insider Gaming Discord.

We‚Äôve got much more ARC Raiders content here at IG. Read about any potential launch Early Access, Crossplay or Cross-Platform capabilities, and if the shooter is coming to Xbox Game Pass.
